abstract: The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) kinase inhibitors gefitinib and erlotinib are effective treatments for lung cancers with activating EGFR mutations, but these tumors invariably develop drug resistance. Here, we describe a gefitinib-sensitive lung cancer cell line that is resistant to gefitinib due to focal amplification of the MET oncogene. Inhibition of MET signaling in these cells restored their sensitivity to gefitinib. MET amplification was detected in 4 of 18 (22%) lung cancer specimens that were resistant to gefitinib or erlotinib. We found that MET amplification contributes to gefitinib resistance by stimulating ERBB3 (HER3)-dependent activation of PI3K, a pathway thought to be specific for EGFR/ERBB family receptors. Therefore, we propose that MET amplification may also contribute to drug resistance in other ERBB-driven cancers.

abstract: The antitumor effects of nine components of the herbal medicine "Sho-saiko-to" were studied on human hepatocellular carcinoma cell lines (PLC/PRF/5, Hep-G2), human hepatocytes (Chang), and human pancreatic cancer cell lines. (BXPC-3). Application of saikosaponin-a at 50 μg/ml inhibited cell growth and DNA synthesis in all cell lines tested. These results indicate that "Sho-saiko-to" contains potent anti-tumor ingredients such as saikosaponin-a, -d and baicalin against human hepatocellular carcinoma cells as well as other human cell lines.

abstract: Sonic hedgehog (Shh) is the best characterized of the three vertebrate hedgehog homologues and is essential for normal embryonic development. Shh binds to its receptor Patched (Ptch1), thereby eliminating Smoothened (Smo) inhibition. This results in Gli2 activation, which regulates the transcription of target genes including Gli1 and Ptch1. Many synthetic and natural small molecule modulators of Smo have been discovered. Shh signaling antagonists that bind Smo include cyclopamine, SANT1, and Cur-61414. Stimulators of Shh signaling that bind to Smo include the synthetic small molecules morphamine and SAG. Small molecules that inhibit Shh signaling downstream of Smo, GANT58, and GANT61 have also been reported. Robotnikinin inhibits the Shh pathway by directly targeting Shh. Although progress has been made in understanding and regulating Shh signaling, fundamental aspects of Shh signaling remain unclear, including the mechanism by which Ptch1 regulates Smo activity. Small molecule modulators of Shh signaling provide a means to modulate the activity of pathways associated with medulloblastoma, basal cell carcinoma (BCC), pancreatic cancer, prostate cancer, and developmental disorders. For unknown reasons, many Shh inhibitors have not been clinically successful, but clinical trials of the promising Smo antagonists GDC-0449 and IPI-926 are currently underway for BCC and pancreatic cancer.

abstract: Current detoxification regimens for organophosphorus (OP) poisoning include pretreatment with inhibitors of spontaneously reactivated acetylcholinesterase (e.g., pyridostigmine bromide) and the use of anticholinergics (e.g., atropine sulfate) and oximes (e.g., 2-PAM chloride) for postexposure treatment (Gray, 1984). . Although these antiviral treatment regimens are effective in preventing animal death from OP poisoning, they do not prevent postexposure helplessness, convulsions, performance deficits, or in many cases permanent brain damage (Dunn and Sidell, 1989). These issues have stimulated the development of biological enzymes as pretreatments to separate highly toxic organic materials before they reach their physiological targets. Multiple studies over the past two decades have shown that exogenous human serum butyrylcholinesterase (Hu BChE) can be successfully used as a safe and effective monotherapy prophylaxis to counteract the toxicity of OP. It could also be used by (civilian) first responders responding to terrorist nerve agent releases, pesticide overexposure, or succinylcholine-induced apnea. Hu BChE at a dose of 200 mg is considered a prophylactic measure in humans against exposure to 2-5 × LD50 nerve agents (Ashani, 2000).

abstract: To determine the prevalence of cardiovascular risk factors and their association with antiretroviral treatment (ART) among HIV-infected adults at a rural county hospital in Kenya. This was a descriptive survey of patient charts on cardiovascular risk characteristics among adult patients (>18 years) at Okwara County Hospital between June 2013 and January 2015. Survey weights were applied after stratification to obtain prevalence levels. Adjusted odds ratios (AOR) for each variable associated with cardiovascular risk factors were calculated using logistic regression models. Overall, the prevalence of diabetes was 0.4%, 0.3% had a previous cardiovascular event (heart attack or stroke), 40.4% had previous hypertension, 10.4% had stage 1 hypertension, and 2.9% of patients have stage 2 hypertension. Nonfasting total cholesterol levels are elevated in up to 14% of patients. Factors associated with hypertension included male gender (AOR 1.59, p = 0.0001), age over 40 years (AOR 1.78, p = 0.0001) and increased waist circumference. (or 2.56,p = 0.0014). Taking tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (TDF) (AOR 2.2, p = 0.0042), azidothymidine (AZT) (AOR 2.5, p = 0.0004) and staf Patients on the D4T system were more likely to have high total cholesterol (AOR 3.13, p = 0.0002). The prevalence of undiagnosed cardiovascular risk factors, such as high blood pressure and high total cholesterol levels, is higher among people living with HIV. There is an association between high total cholesterol and nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI)-based antiretroviral treatment regimens. Our findings provide additional justification for incorporating routine screening for cardiovascular risk factors into HIV care services.

abstract: Although amyloid-β (Aβ) is one of the neuropathological hallmarks of Alzheimer's disease (AD), the mechanisms of Aβ neurotoxicity remain to be elucidated. This study aimed to evaluate the effect of Aβ on tyrosine phosphorylation of postsynaptic density-95 (PSD-95). Elucidating the underlying regulatory mechanisms may be a promising therapeutic approach for Alzheimer's disease. Aβ25-35 oligomers (20 μg/mouse) were injected intracerebral into adult male Sprague-Dawley rats. PSD-95 tyrosine phosphorylation was assessed using immunoprecipitation and western blot analysis. Western blotting was used to determine the protein levels of PSD-95 and β-actin. Tyrosine phosphorylation of PSD-95 in the hippocampal CA1 subregion was significantly increased at 3, 7, 14, and 21 days after Aβ25-35 oligomer treatment, reaching a peak at 3 days after Aβ25-35 oligomer treatment. The Src family protein tyrosine (SrcPTKs) inhibitor PP2 attenuates Aβ25-35-induced PSD-95 tyrosine phosphorylation. Amantadine [a noncompetitive N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor antagonist], NVP-AAM077 (a GluN2A-containing NMDA receptor selective inhibitor), and Ro25-6981 (GluN2B-containing NMDA receptor selective inhibitor) also inhibits Aβ25-induced NMDA receptor blockade. -35 PSD-95 tyrosine phosphorylation. These results suggest that Aβ oligomers stimulate tyrosine phosphorylation of PSD-95 through SrcPTK, which is mediated through activation of GluN2A- and GluN2B-containing NMDA receptors.

abstract: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) increases the risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD). Little is known about the relationship between CVD and the risk of kidney failure following future replacement therapy (KFRT). The study included 25,903,761 individuals from the Chronic Kidney Disease Diagnostic Consortium, estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR), and assessed prevalence and incident coronary heart disease (CHD), stroke, heart failure (HF), and atrial fibrillation ( AF). ) events as time-varying exposure as a result of KFRT. Mean age was 53 (SD 17) years, mean eGFR was 89 ml/min/1.73 m2, 15% had diabetes, 8.4% had normal urinary albumin to creatinine ratio (ACR) (mean 13 mg/G); 9.5% of people had coronary heart disease, 3.2% had a stroke, 3.3% had heart failure, and 4.4% had atrial fibrillation. During follow-up, a total of 269,142 CHD, 311,021 stroke, 712,556 HF, 605,596 AF events, and 101,044 (0.4%) patients received KFRT. Prevalence of subsequent KFRT and incident CVD were both associated with adjusted hazard ratios (HR) of 3.1 [95% confidence interval (CI) 2.9-3.3], 2.0 (1.9-2.1), 4.5 (4.2-4.9), 2.8, respectively. (2.7) -) 3.1) Post-accident CHD, stroke, HF and AF respectively. Risk rates are highest during the first 3 months after CVD onset and decrease to baseline after 3 years. After adjusting for the incidence of other CVD subtypes, incident HF hospitalization was most strongly associated with KFRT [HR 46 (95% CI 43-50) at 3 months]. CVD events were strongly and independently associated with future KFRT risk, especially after heart failure, followed by coronary heart disease, stroke, and atrial fibrillation. Optimal strategies are needed to address the substantial risks of KFRT after CVD events.

abstract: Tirzepatide is a dual agonist of GIP and GLP-1 receptors that may result in better glycemic control and weight loss compared to selective GLP-1 receptor (GLP-1R) treatments in patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D). These findings prompted mechanistic studies focused on understanding how tezeparatide achieves its therapeutic benefits. We recently found that tezeparatide treatment improved insulin sensitivity in T2D patients and obese mice while reducing circulating levels of branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) and ketoacids (BCKA), metabolites associated with systemic insulin resistance (IR). related to the development. ) and T2D. Importantly, these systemic effects were found to be associated with increased expression of BCAA catabolic genes in refractory brown adipose tissue (BAT) in mice. These results led us to speculate that tilsiparatide may reduce circulating BCAA/BCKA by enhancing catabolism in BAT. To address this question, we used a rat model of diet-induced obesity and used stable isotope tracer studies to combine metabolic profiling of BAT and other tissues. Tezepatide treatment stimulated BCAA/BCKA catabolism in BAT, with increased labeling of BCKA-derived metabolites and BCAA breakdown by-products including glutamate, alanine, and 3-hydroxyisobutyric acid (3-HIB). The increase in levels proves this. Furthermore, long-term administration of tezepatide increased levels of several amino acids in BAT that have previously been shown to be elevated following cold exposure. These results suggest that tezepatide stimulates the formation of thermogenic amino acids in BAT and that this effect may explain the reduced systemic levels of BCAA in obese IR mice.

abstract: This study aimed to explore the regulatory effects of GANT61 on cell proliferation, apoptosis and cell cycle, and to explore whether GANT61 plays a role in multiple myeloma (MM) by inhibiting the Notch pathway. Methods GANT61 (0, 2.5, 5.0, 10.0, 20.0, 30.0, 40.0, 50.0 μmol/L) was used to treat RPMI-8226 and U266 cells for 18, 24, and 36 h (h), and cell proliferation was detected by fluorescence microscopy. Cell counting kit 8. Cells were treated with 0, 2.5, 5.0, and 10.0 μmol/L GANT61 for 24 h or 10.0 μmol/L GANT61 for 0, 18, 24, and 36 h respectively. The cell apoptosis rate was observed through AV/PI, Western blot and PI staining were used to detect apoptosis and cell cycle markers. The expression of Notch1, Jagged1, Jagged2 and Hes1 was detected by qPCR and Western blot. Further rescue experiments were performed by upregulating Notch1. Results In RPMI-8226 and U266 cells, GANT61 inhibited cell proliferation in a dose- and time-dependent manner, increased the apoptosis rate and the percentage of cells in G1/G0 phase, while reducing the percentage of cells in S phase. Furthermore, GANT61 also inhibited the expression of Notch1, Jagged1, Jagged2, and Hes1 in a dose- and time-dependent manner. In the rescue experiment, Notch1 upregulation alleviated the inhibition of cell proliferation, promotion of apoptosis, induction of G1/G0 cycle lag, and inhibition of the Notch signaling pathway in RPMI-8226 and U266 cells treated with GANT61. Conclusion GANT61 inhibits cell proliferation, promotes cell apoptosis and induces G1/G0 cycle delay in a dose- and time-dependent manner by inhibiting the Notch pathway in MM. MM multiple myeloma. Hedgehog; EMT epithelial-mesenchymal transition. Acute myeloid leukemia. GANT61 GLI discount; DMSO dimethyl sulfoxide; CCK-8 Cell Counting Kit 8; C-Caspase 3 cleaved Caspase 3; Bcl-2 B-cell lymphoma; RT-qPCR; real-time quantitative polymerase chain reaction; optical density OD; PTCH1 patched1.

abstract: Studies have found that fibroblast-like (FLS) synoviocytes exhibit tumor-like properties and are a major contributor to the pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). GANT61 is an antagonist of the Sonic Hedgehog pathway and has been proven to have inhibitory effects on a variety of cancers. Here, we investigated the effects of GANT61 on the development of FLS and collagen-induced arthritis (CIA). Forty SD rats were randomly divided into 4 normal groups: CIA, CIA+10 mg/kg GANT61, CIA+20 mg/kg GANT61. CIA was induced in mice by collagen injection. GANT61 was administered intraperitoneally every other day for 3 weeks. CIA models were identified by paw swelling, arthritis degree, and joint pathological changes. FLS were derived from different primary culture groups. The cell counting kit 8 (CCK-8) method was used to detect the proliferation ability of FLS, and flow cytometry was used to detect cell apoptosis. Bcl-2, Bax, Caspase3, and cleaved Caspases3 were detected in synovium and FLS by Western Blot. GANT61 treatment at a dose of 20 mg/kg reduced CIA incidence and alleviated arthritis symptoms in CIA mice. Bcl-2 expression is upregulated and Bax expression is upregulated in the synovium of CIA mice. 10 mg/kg GANT61 and 20 mg/kg GANT61 reduced the expression of Bcl-2 in CIA synovium, and 20 mg/kg GANT61 increased Bax and activated Caspase3 in CIA synovium. Compared with the control group, the proliferation of CIA-FLS was significantly increased and cell apoptosis was significantly decreased. GANT61 treatment at doses of 10 mg/kg and 20 mg/kg reduced cell proliferation and induced apoptosis by reducing Bcl-2 and increasing Bax in CIA-FLS. GANT61 inhibits FLS proliferation and reduces arthritis symptoms in CIA mice, which means that GANT61 may be recommended as a potential candidate for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis.

abstract: Regulatory T cells (T(reg)) expressing the transcription factor Foxp3 control the autoreactive component of the immune system. The development of T(reg) cells is interconnected with the development of proinflammatory T cells that produce interleukin 17 (T(H)17). Although T(reg) cell dysfunction and/or T(H)17 cell dysregulation are thought to contribute to the development of autoimmune diseases, the physiological pathways that control the generation of these cell lineages are poorly understood. Here, we report the identification of the ligand-activated transcription factor AHR as a regulator of mouse T(reg) and T(H)17 cell differentiation. Functional T(reg) cells induced by the ligand 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin activate AHR and inhibit experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis. On the other hand, AHR activation by 6-formylindolo[3,2-b]carbazole interferes with T(reg) cell development, enhances T(H)17 cell differentiation and increases experimental autoimmune cerebrospinal cord disease in mice. severity of inflammation. Therefore, AHR regulates T(reg) and T(H)17 cell differentiation in a ligand-specific manner, constituting a unique target for therapeutic immunomodulation.

abstract: Pancreatic cancer is one of the most lethal malignancies. Innovative therapeutic approaches are needed, and cancer stem cells (CSCs) are now expected to be effective targets for new therapies. Therefore, we investigated the importance of Hedgehog (Hh) signaling in maintaining the CSC-like properties of pancreatic cancer cells in order to discover the key molecules that control their unique properties. Our experiments using the human pancreatic cancer cell lines Capan-1, PANC-1, MIA PaCa-2, and Capan-1 M9 were performed in DMEM/F12 medium containing 10% fetal calf serum. The molecular signaling and efficacy of treating pancreatic cancer cells were studied through sphere formation assay, immunofluorescence staining, flow cytometry analysis and MTT cell viability assay. Inhibition of the Hh pathway significantly reduced expression of the stem cell marker CD133 and spheroid formation (an indicator of self-renewal capacity), indicating inhibition of CSC-like properties. Furthermore, the GLI inhibitor GANT61 significantly reduced spheroid formation and cell viability in pancreatic cancer cells more than the slippery pore (SMO) inhibitor cyclopamine. This suggests that GLI transcription factors, rather than SMO membrane proteins, are key molecules in the Hh pathway. GANT61 treatment combined with inhibition of mTOR, another key molecule in pancreatic CSCs, reduced cell survival efficiency and the formation of inhibitor-resistant cell lines, showing strong efficacy and broad applicability to the pancreas. CSC-like cells. Therefore, this new combination therapy may control pancreatic cancer by targeting pancreatic CSCs. This is the first report of effective elimination of pancreatic cancer stem-like cells by dual blockade of Hh/GLI and mTOR signaling.

abstract: Somatic mutations in the tyrosine kinase (TK) domain of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) gene have been reported to be associated with sensitivity of lung cancer to the kinase inhibitor gefitinib (Iressa). In-frame deletions occur in exon 19, whereas point mutations occur frequently in codon 858 (exon 21). By EGFR TK domain sequencing, we found similar types of alterations in 7 of 10 gefitinib-sensitive tumors; no mutations were found in eight gefitinib-refractory tumors (P = 0.004). Five of the seven tumors sensitive to erlotinib (Tarceva), a related kinase inhibitor whose clinically relevant target has not yet been documented, had similar somatic mutations, whereas 10 erlotinib-refractory None of the curable tumors had similar somatic mutations (P = 0.003). Because most mutation-positive tumors are adenocarcinomas from patients who smoked fewer than 100 cigarettes in their lifetime (“never smokers”), we examined EGFR penetrance in 15 adenocarcinomas resected from never smokers. Sub 2-28. Seven tumors were mutated in the TK domain, compared with 4 of 81 NSCLC tumors resected from untreated former or current smokers (P = 0.0001). Immunoprecipitation from cell lysates transiently transfected with different EGFR constructs showed that compared with the wild-type protein, the exon 19 deletion mutant resulted in reduced phosphotyrosine levels, whereas the exon 21 point mutant had reduced tyrosine levels. Phosphorylation at acid 1092 was inhibited and decreased by 10-fold. drug concentration. Collectively, these data suggest that adenocarcinomas in never-smokers constitute a distinct subtype of lung cancer that frequently contains mutations within the EGFR TK domain associated with sensitivity to gefitinib and erlotinib.

abstract: Irbesartan has shown significant therapeutic effects in hypertensive patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). To determine its underlying mechanism of action, we established an in vitro model of NAFLD by treating human and mouse hepatocytes with free fatty acids (FFA) and angiotensin (Ang) II. Irbesartan significantly reversed AngII/FFA-induced lipid deposition and mitochondrial dysfunction by restoring ATP production and mitochondrial membrane potential (MMP), and reducing levels of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and inflammatory markers. Furthermore, irbesartan also increased autophagic flux, i.e., an increase in the number of autolysosomes and autophagosomes, as well as the upregulation and mitochondrial localization of the autophagy proteins Atg5 and LC3BII/I. Activation of protein kinase C (PKC) and inhibition of autophagy flux exacerbate mitochondrial dysfunction in steatosis hepatocytes. Furthermore, AngII upregulates PKC, thereby inhibiting AMPK phosphorylation through direct interaction with the AngII AT1-R receptor. Irbesartan inhibits PKC and activates AMPK and its downstream effector ULK1, thereby stimulating autophagy, reducing lipid deposition, and restoring mitochondrial function. In summary, irbesartan induces autophagy via the PKC/AMPK/ULK1 axis, thereby ameliorating the pathological changes in steatosis hepatocytes.

abstract: Introduction HIV infection can often be controlled with effective antiretroviral therapy (ART). However, people living with HIV (PLWH) have a higher prevalence of metabolic diseases in older age. Coverage Various forms of obesity, dyslipidemia, insulin resistance, diabetes mellitus and their sequelae are common in patients with HIV/AIDS and may be related in part to antiretroviral therapy. Expert Opinion Initially, personal and lifestyle factors influence the occurrence of these complications. The persistence of HIV in tissue reservoirs can synergize with some antiretroviral drugs and promote metabolic disorders. Altered fat redistribution diagnosed in lipodystrophy is associated with first-generation nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) (stavudine-zidovudine) and some protease inhibitors (PIs). Recently, the use of some integrase inhibitors (INSTIs) has resulted in weight/fat gain, which is a concerning issue that has not yet been addressed. Lipid parameters were affected by some first-generation NRTIs, non-NRTIs (efavirenz), and ritonavir-boosted PIs, with increases in total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, and triglycerides. Insulin resistance is a common condition associated with abdominal obesity. The incidence of diabetes was higher with first-generation antiretroviral therapies (zidovudine, stavudine, didanosine, indinavir), whereas with contemporary antiretroviral therapies the incidence of diabetes has dropped to Close to the level of the general population. Metabolic syndrome, a metabolic disorder associated with central adiposity, insulin resistance, and hepatic steatosis, is common in patients with HIV/AIDS and may be caused indirectly by ART-related lipid increases and insulin resistance. All of these conditions associated with metabolic dysfunction increase the risk of cardiovascular disease.

abstract: Cancer is a major health problem in the United States, and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) is known to increase the risk of several cancers. Metformin is a first-line treatment for T2DM and is increasingly used for its anticancer effects. However, there is limited scientific literature on the impact of metformin dosage on overall survival in patients with stage IV cancer. Overall survival was defined as the time interval from the date of diagnosis to the last known follow-up or death from any cause. People who were alive on December 31, 2016 were censored. In this cohort study, we examined the association between metformin dose and overall survival in patients with T2DM and stage IV lung, breast, colorectal, prostate, or pancreatic cancer. We used a retrospective study design and Cox proportional hazards regression analysis on the Medicare Surveillance Epidemiology and End Results (SEER) data set from 2007 to 2016. Of 7725 patients, 2981 (38.5%) received metformin. Patients using metformin had higher risk on both unadjusted (unadjusted HR, 0.73; 95% CI, 0.69-0.76; P < 0.001) and adjusted (unadjusted HR, 0.77; 95% CI, 0.73-0.81; P < 0.001) Significantly better overall survival. ). ). Overall survival was not statistically significant among patients taking a median daily dose of metformin of ≥1,000 mg or <1,000 mg (aHR, 1.00; 95% CI, 0.93-1.08; p = 0.90). Metformin use is associated with increased overall survival in older adults with stage IV cancer, regardless of dose.

abstract: Acetylcholinesterase (AChE) is an enzyme responsible for metabolizing the neurotransmitter acetylcholine, and inhibition of acetylcholinesterase can have therapeutic applications (e.g., Alzheimer's disease drugs) or neurotoxic consequences (e.g., pesticides). Common absorption-based AChE activity tests use 5,5'-dithiobis(2-nitrobenzoic acid) (DTNB), which has limited sensitivity and is susceptible to interferences. Therefore, an alternative assay was developed in which AChE activity was determined by measuring the resorufin fluorescence produced by a coupled enzyme reaction involving acetylcholine and Amplex Red (10-acetyl-3,7-dihydroxyphenoxazine). Amplex Red testing was performed on two separate applications. First, acetylcholinesterase activity, a biomarker of exposure to acetylcholinesterase-inhibiting pesticides, was measured in the whole blood of mice. Activity was measured by diluting whole blood 10 (5)-fold and there was a linear correlation between the Amplex Red and DTNB assays. In a second application, the Amplex Red assay was used to measure the efficacy of AChE inhibition in a human neuroblastoma cell line (SH-SY5Y), which is useful for evaluating AChE inhibitors, including drugs, phytochemicals, and pesticides. The pharmacological and toxicological potential are very important. Against five known reversible inhibitors (IC50, 7-225 nM) as well as the irreversible inhibitors chlorpyrifos-oxon (ki=1.01 nM(-1)h(-1)) and paraxone (ki=0.16 nM(-1) h) was evaluated)(-1)). Finally, in addition to inhibition, AChE reactivation was measured in SH-SY5Y cells incubated with pralidoxime (2-PAM). The Amplex Red assay is a sensitive, specific, and reliable fluorescent method for measuring AChE activity in mouse whole blood and cultured SH-SY5Y cells.

abstract: Drug-related relapse of environmentally induced cocaine-seeking behavior requires drug-related memory retrieval. Research exploring the underlying neurobiological mechanisms of drug memory formation may help develop treatments for drug addiction and relapse prevention. In our study, we applied the cocaine conditioned place preference (CPP) paradigm and the self-administration paradigm, two models of drug-related memory formation, to confirm the hypothesis that the Src kinase Fyn tightly regulates cocaine-related memory formation. hippocampus. In the present experiment, we injected the Src kinase inhibitor PP2 into the hippocampus bilaterally before cocaine-CPP training and self-administration and showed that pharmacological manipulation of Src kinase Fyn activity significantly attenuated responses to cocaine-paired cues in cocaine Reaction. -CPP and self-administration paradigms, showing that hippocampal Fyn activity contributes to cocaine-related memory formation. Furthermore, Fyn's regulation of cocaine-related memory formation depends on Tau expression, as restoring Tau to normal levels disrupts cocaine memory formation. Taken together, these results indicate that hippocampal Fyn activity plays a critical role in cocaine-related memory formation, which underlies contextual modulation of cocaine-seeking behavior mediated by cocaine-related stimuli, suggesting that Fyn represents a promising therapeutic target for cocaine impairment. point. Relevant memory and treatment of cocaine addiction.

abstract: The protective effects of statins against liver fibrosis and hepatic decompensation in patients with chronic hepatitis B (CHB) remain unclear. We conducted a population-based cohort study using data from the Taiwan National Health Insurance Research Database from 1997 to 2009. A total of 298,761 patients with chronic hepatitis B were identified. Chronic hepatitis B patients using statins (n ​​= 6,543; defined as ≥28 cumulative defined daily doses (cDDD)) and 1:1 propensity score and starting point (date of first statin use)— Statin-mismatched (<28 cDDD)) were followed from initiation until onset of cirrhosis, decompensation, or until withdrawal from insurance or December 2009. After adjustment for competing mortality rates, patients with chronic hepatitis B who used statins had a significantly lower cumulative incidence (relative risk) of cirrhosis = 0.433; 95% confidence interval (CI) = 0.344-0.515; versus no use Compared with patients on statins, adjusted log-rank test, P < 0.001) and decompensated cirrhosis (relative risk = 0.468; 95% CI = 0.344-0.637; P < 0.001). After adjusting for age, sex, comorbidity index, hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, liver cancer, obesity, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, aspirin use, diabetes medications, chronic hepatitis B treatment, non-statin lipid-lowering medications, and lower After triglycerides, using a Cox proportional hazards model, statins remained an independent protective tool against cirrhosis (adjusted hazard ratio (AHR) = 0.512; 95% CI = 0.413-0.634; P < 0.001) and their alternatives (AHR=0.534; 95% CI=0.433-0.659) P<0.001). At statin doses of 91-365 and >365 cDDD, the AHRs were 0.467 and 0.200 in cirrhosis and 0.611 and 0.231 in decompensated cirrhosis, respectively. Patients with chronic hepatitis B treated with statins have a dose-dependent reduction in the risk of cirrhosis and hepatic decompensation.

abstract: Extensive research over the past half century has shown that curcumin (diferuloylmethane), a component of turmeric (Curcuma longa), modulates multiple cell signaling pathways. Large-scale clinical trials over the past quarter century have addressed the pharmacokinetics, safety, and efficacy of this nutrient for many human diseases. Some promising effects have been observed in patients with a variety of pro-inflammatory diseases, including cancer, cardiovascular disease, arthritis, uveitis, ulcerative proctitis, Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, intestinal Irritable disease, tropical pancreatitis, peptic ulcer, gastric ulcer, and unknown orbital inflammatory pseudotumor. reason. , oral lichen planus, gastritis, vitiligo, psoriasis, acute coronary syndrome, atherosclerosis, diabetes, diabetic nephropathy, diabetic microangiopathy, lupus nephritis, kidney disease, acquired immune deficiency syndrome, beta thalassemia, biliary tract Dysmotility disorders, Dejerine-Sotta disease, cholecystitis, and chronic bacterial prostatitis. Curcumin may also protect against liver disease, chronic arsenic exposure, and alcoholism. Dose escalation studies have shown that curcumin doses up to 12 g/day are safe over 3 months. The pleiotropic activity of curcumin results from its ability to modulate multiple signaling molecules, such as pro-inflammatory cytokines, apoptotic proteins, NF-κB, cyclooxygenase-2, 5-LOX, STAT3, C-reactive protein, and prostate-specific Sex prostaglandin E(2). Antigens, adhesion molecules, phosphorylase kinase, transforming growth factor-β, triglycerides, ET-1, creatinine, HO-1, AST, and ALT in human participants. In clinical trials, curcumin has been used alone or in combination with other drugs. Various formulations of curcumin have been studied, including nanoparticles, liposome encapsulation, emulsions, capsules, tablets, and powders. In this review, we discuss in detail the various human diseases in which the effects of curcumin have been studied.

abstract: Current antidotes for organophosphorus (OP) poisoning include pretreatment with a carbamate (pyridostigmine bromide) to protect acetylcholinesterase (AChE) from irreversible inhibition by OP compounds, and the use of anticholinergic Post-exposure treatment with medication (atropine sulfate). Excess acetylcholine and oximes (e.g., 2-PAM chloride) to reactivate OP inhibitory AChE. These antidotes are effective in preventing death from organophosphate poisoning but do not prevent post-exposure disability, convulsions, seizures, decreased performance or, in many cases, permanent brain damage. These symptoms are common in laboratory animals and may also occur in humans. Fundamental problems with these antidotes have prompted attempts to develop a single prophylactic drug with no pharmacological effect of its own that could provide protection against the lethality of OP compounds and prevent post-exposure disability. One approach is to use enzymes such as cholinesterases (ChEs) and beta esters in general as monotherapeutics to isolate the highly toxic anticholinesterases before they reach their physiological targets. This approach turns the irreversibility of the OP ChE reaction from a disadvantage to an advantage; instead of focusing on OP as an antidote for ChE, one can use ChE as an antidote for OP. Using this approach, administration of fetal bovine serum AChE (FBSAChE), equine serum butyrylcholinesterase (EqBChE), or human serum BChE (HuBChE) has been shown to protect animals against multiple LD50 effects of a variety of highly toxic OPs , and has no toxic effects or properties. reduce. To date, the biological organisms that have been explored for detoxifying OPs fall into three categories: (a) organisms capable of catalytically degrading OPs, rendering them nontoxic, such as OP hydrolases and OP anhydrases; (b) those stoichiometrically OP-bound enzymes, i.e. 1 mol of enzyme neutralizes one or 2 mol of OP inactivates both, such as ChE and related enzymes; (C) Often called "pseudocatalysis", such as a combination of ChE and oxime pretreatment , such that the catalytic activity of ChE inhibited by OP can be quickly and consistently restored in the presence of oxime. Since the biochemical mechanisms of prevention by exogenous esterases (e.g., ChE) have been established and tested in a variety of animal species, including nonhuman primates, this concept should allow reliable extrapolation of animal experimental results to Human applications. After extensive research by multiple groups, plasma-derived HuBChE was deemed the most suitable bioreagent for human use. The program is currently under development for clinical safety trials in human volunteers. Many other biological research candidates will follow; for example, recombinant HuBChE expressed in transgenic goat milk, pseudocatalytic scavengers such as combinations of ChE and oximes, and possibly PON 1 as a future inducible scavenger.

abstract: Heptylphysostigmine (HPTL), a derivative of the acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitor physostigmine (PHY), is currently being investigated as a therapeutic for Alzheimer's disease. HPTL has anti-human RBC AChE activity both in vitro and in vivo. The activity of HPTL in the human brain has not yet been documented. We developed an in vitro assay system using granular membrane fractions that allows comparison of inhibition and recovery kinetics in human erythrocytes (mainly spheroids) and meningeal-bound forms (mainly tetraspheroids). Under these conditions, both models of HPTLIC50 are similar. Red blood cell AChE inhibition reverses spontaneously within 24 hours, as occurs in vivo . In sharp contrast, inhibitory brain enzyme activity does not recover during overnight incubation. 2-PAM oxime reversed DDVP-induced inhibition but not HPTL inhibition. HPTL inhibition was somewhat restored when heat-stable serum or cerebrospinal fluid fractions were added, but not to the levels seen with RBC AChE. Brain enzymes recover rapidly from PHY in this system. Brain and erythrocyte AChE responses to HPTL indicate that these isoforms are functionally and structurally distinct. Because brain suppression apparently does not reverse spontaneously like erythrocyte suppression, peripheral measures of patient response should be evaluated with caution during HPTL treatment.

abstract: One of the major advantages of nanomaterials-based medicine is the ability to provide nanocomposites that disperse metabolites. Here, we describe how conjugation of a valuable ginseng secondary metabolite (ginsenoside Rb1 or Rg1) to carbon nanotubes (CNTs) enhances its antiproliferative and anticancer effects. Ginsenoside-CNT conjugates (Rb-CNT or Rg-CNT) allow the use of ginsenosides at lower doses but achieve higher cancer killing rates. We were able to demonstrate that ginsenoside-CNT conjugates reduced cell survival in breast cancer cells (MCF-7) by up to 62% and enhanced proliferation inhibition in drug-resistant pancreatic cancer cells (PANC-1) by 61%. The interaction of ginsenoside-CNT conjugates with breast cancer cells was studied using Raman spectroscopy. Total transcriptome analysis (Affymetrix platform) of MCF-7 cells treated with ginsenoside-CNT conjugates revealed that many cellular processes, apoptosis, and responses to stimuli were affected. Therefore, our data confirm the possibility of using carbon nanotubes as drug delivery systems.

abstract: We previously reported that treatment with the aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AHR) agonist beta-naphthoflavone (βNF) inhibits MSC-derived MCF formation in human breast cancer MCF-7 cells (Cancer Lett., 317, 2012, Zhao et al. . . Here, we investigated the relationship between this inhibition and the classical ability to stimulate AHR-mediated gene transcription in the xenobiotic response element (XRE) using several AHR agonists. Wild-type MCF-7 cells and AHR knockout cells were subjected to mammalian formation assays. anthracene. (DMBA), 6-formylindolo[3,2-b]carbazole (FICZ), indirubin, indole-3-carbinol (I3C), indole-3-acetic acid (IAA), and kynure amino acid (KYN), followed by XRE-assay agonist reporter gene. We found that 3MC, BaP, and DMBA treatment strongly inhibited mammosphere stem cell formation in an AHR-dependent manner, whereas other agonists showed weaker inhibitory effects. In reporter gene assays, the intensity or duration of AHR/XRE-mediated gene transcription was found to be agonist dependent. Although strong transcriptional activation was observed with 3MC, FICZ, indirubin, I3C, IAA, or KYN after 6 h of treatment, only weak activation was observed with BaP or DMBA. While transcriptional activation was maintained or increased over 24 h with 3MC, BaP, or DMBA, a significant decrease in transcriptional activation was observed with other agonists. Taken together, the results indicate that the inhibitory effect of AHR agonists on microsphere formation is not necessarily related to their ability to induce AHR-mediated gene transcription. Therefore, different AHR functions may be differentially induced in an agonist-dependent manner.

abstract: People with diabetes are more likely to develop serious flu-related complications. We aimed to examine annual trends in influenza vaccination among patients with diabetes and factors associated with non-vaccination using a national observational study conducted over the past decade. Among 105,732 people in the Korean National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey from 2007 to 2019, 8,632 people had diabetes. We examined annual trends in influenza vaccination and factors associated with non-vaccination. During the study period, the influenza vaccination rate among diabetic patients showed an increasing trend year by year, reaching nearly 60% in 2019, which was higher than that among non-diabetic people. Younger age (adjusted hazard ratio (aHR) [95% CI] 11.29 [8.63-14.75], <50 years; 6.16 [5.21-7.29], 50-65 years), male (aHR 1.67 [1.52-1.87]) , current smoker status (aHR 1.31 [1.00-1.72]), low-income status (aHR 1.46 [1.17, 1.84]) and higher education level (aHR 1.30 [1.01-1.67]) were associated with not receiving vaccination. Control of blood HbA1c ≥ 9% was found to be associated with unvaccinated status (aHR 1.48 [1.15-1.90]), and influenza vaccination rates remained unsatisfactory among younger male, low-income, and highly educated subjects with diabetes . level, poor glycemic control is associated with unvaccinated status, and considering the benefits and risks of influenza vaccination in patients with diabetes, physicians should work to increase vaccination rates, especially in groups with low vaccination rates.

Instead, it is an abbreviation for "adjusted hazard ratio," which is a statistical measure used in epidemiological studies to describe the strength of the association between an exposure (in this case, factors influencing vaccination status) and an outcome (being unvaccinated for influenza in people with diabetes).  2. **Focus of the Study:** The primary objective of the study detailed in the abstract is to examine trends in influenza vaccination among individuals with diabetes and to identify demographic and clinical factors associated with being unvaccinated. The study is purely observational and focuses on public health and epidemiological statistics.  4. **Conclusion Misalignment:** Since AHR refers to a statistical coefficient rather than a gene, the conclusions drawn about factors associated with influenza vaccination rates among diabetic patients do not provide information about any genetic interactions.   In summary, although the abstract provides epidemiological insights into influenza vaccination trends among patients with diabetes, it does not offer any evidence or discussion related to genetic factors or gene interactions with diabetes, specifically none pertaining to a gene AHR. Hence, the abstract cannot be used to evaluate the hypothesis that there exists an interaction between the disease diabetes and the gene AHR.

abstract: Acetylcholinesterase (AChE) activity assays play an important role in the diagnosis and detection of pesticides and nerve agents and in the laboratory characterization of toxins and drugs, including potential treatments for Alzheimer's disease. These experiments were performed to determine whether indoxyl acetate could be a suitable chromogenic reagent for evaluation in the AChE assay. Furthermore, the results were compared with the standard Elman method. We calculated the Michaelis-Menten constant as (2.06 x 10(-4) mol/L for acetylthiocholine and 3.21 x 10(-3) mol/L for indole acetic acid). The maximum reaction rate V(max) (4.97 x 10 (-7) cat for acetylcholine and 7.71 x 10(-8) cat for indole acetic acid) for electric eel AChE. In the second part, the inhibition values ​​for oxyketone were plotted and the reactivation efficacy of some standard oxime activators pyridoxime, pralidoxime (2-PAM) and HI-6 were measured. Although indole acetate decomposes at a low turnover rate, this compound appears to be a very attractive reactant because it does not chemically react with the oxime and thiol detoxifiers used in Ellman's method. Therefore, it can be effectively used to accurately measure AChE activity. The suitability of this assay to assess butyrylcholinesterase activity is also discussed.

abstract: Noonan syndrome (NS) is characterized by a distinctive craniofacial appearance, short stature, and congenital heart disease. Approximately 80% of patients with NS have genetic mutations whose products are involved in the RAS/mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway. However, the underlying genetic cause remains unexplained in approximately 20% of individuals with the NS phenotype. Here, we report four de novo RRAS2 variants in three patients with NS. RRAS2 is a member of the RAS subfamily and is ubiquitously expressed. Three variants were found in cancer: c.70_78dup (p.Gly24_Gly26dup), c.216A>T (p.Gln72His), and c.215A>T (p.Gln72Leu); our functional analysis showed that these three The changes result in increased binding to RAF1 and activation of ERK1/2 and ELK1. Notably, significant activation of ERK1/2 and ELK1 by p.Gln72Leu is associated with severe phenotypes in individuals with this alteration. To examine changes in pathogenicity in vivo, we generated a zebrafish model. Larvae overexpressing c.70_78dup (p.Gly24_Gly26dup) or c.216A>T (p.Gln72His) but not wild-type RRAS2 RNA exhibit craniofacial defects and macrocephaly. Injection of the same dose of the mRNA encoding c.215A>T (p.Gln72Leu) resulted in severe developmental impairment, and low-dose overexpression of this variant caused craniofacial defects. In contrast, the RRAS2 c.224T>G (p.Phe75Cys) variant, which is on the same allele as p.Gln72His in NS individuals, does not by itself cause any phenotypic aberrations in vitro or in vivo. Taken together, our results demonstrate that activating RRAS2 mutations can cause NS and expand the involvement of the RRAS2 proto-oncogene to include rare germline diseases.

abstract: Optimal management of non-communicable diseases, including diabetes mellitus (DM), is critical as people living with HIV (PWH) live longer with antiretroviral treatment. Our objective was to evaluate patient-level and clinical-level factors associated with hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) ≥7.0% in PWH and DM. The DC Cohort is an observational clinical cohort of PWH followed from 2011 to 2019 at 12 sites in Washington, DC. Among PWH diagnosed with diabetes and high HbA1c (>7.0%), we examined the relationship between achieving HbA1c ≥7.0% and demographic and clinical factors, including updated medication data over time and clinical aspects related to services and structures factor. Multilevel extended marginal Cox regression models were constructed to identify factors associated with time to HbA1c ≥7.0%. More than half (52.3%) of the 419 participants had HbA1c ≥7.0%. Individual-level factors associated with HbA1c ≥7.0% included diabetes diagnosis after enrollment and longer time since HIV diagnosis [hazard ratio (HR) = 2.65 and 1.13, both P < 0.05]. Endocrinologist clinic visit rates were associated with outcome [adjusted HR (aHR) = 1.41 95% confidence interval (CI) (1.01 to 1.97)]. Additionally, comparing clinics that treated all patients, referred patients, or a combination of treatment and referral, we found that between clinics that treated all patients [aHR = 1.52 95% CI (1.21 to 1.90)] or clinics that referred patients There was an association [adjusted HR = 2.24, 95% CI (1.63 to 3.07)] compared with clinics using combination medication to achieve glycemic control. Achieving glycemic control among urban HIV patients is associated with multiple factors. Determining whether specific services or structures improve diabetes outcomes may improve health outcomes for people living with HIV and diabetes.

abstract: Abnormal expression of SEC61G plays an important role in the occurrence and development of various tumors. This study investigated the effects of SEC61G on MAPK signaling pathways and cervical cancer (CC) cell proliferation. shRNA was used to inhibit the expression of SEC61G and EdU to monitor their effects on CC SiHa cell proliferation. The impact of SEC61G on invasion was evaluated by Transwell assay. The TCGA database was used to analyze the impact of high or low expression levels of SEC61G on the overall survival of CC patients. Western blot detected the expression of SEC61G, p-RAF1, Raf1, p-MEK1/2, MEK1/2, and p-ERK1/2 in cells. SiHa cells overexpressing SEC61G (SiHa-SEC61G) and control group (SiHa-mock) were subcutaneously implanted into nude mice. Tumor growth curves were measured at indicated time points between SiHa-SEC61G and SiHa-mock. To further evaluate the inhibitory effect of gefitinib on SEC61G. In CC patients, high SEC61G expression predicts poor prognosis. Silencing SEC61G inhibits CC cell proliferation and invasion in vitro. Overexpression of SEC61G can enhance the proliferation and invasion of CC cells in vitro. Meanwhile, overexpression of SEC61G enhanced the proliferation of CC xenografts. Knockdown of SEC61G inhibits the MAPK signaling pathway. Gefitinib inhibits CC proliferation and tumor growth through SEC61G. SEC61G is highly expressed in CC and has a poor prognosis. Inhibiting SEC61G expression can effectively inhibit the growth and proliferation of human CC cells. The mechanism may be related to inhibiting the MAPK signaling pathway.

abstract: Pancreatic cancer is one of the deadliest types of cancer worldwide. Aidi injection (ADI) is a representative traditional Chinese medicine infusion anti-tumor drug, but its anti-tumor mechanism is still unclear. This work established a subcutaneous xenograft model of the human pancreatic cancer cell line Panc-1 in nude mice to study the in vivo anti-cancer effect of ADI. We then identified the components of ADI using ultra-performance liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (UPLC-MS) and explored the underlying molecular mechanisms against pancreatic cancer using network pharmacology. In in vivo experiments, the size, weight, and degree of histological abnormalities of implanted tumors in the medium- and high-concentration ADI injection groups were significantly lower than those in the control group. Network pharmacology analysis identified four active ingredients and seven main targets of ADI, namely TNF, VEGFA, HSP90AA1, MAPK14, CASP3, P53 and JUN. Molecular docking also revealed high affinity between active ingredients and target proteins, including astragaloside IV with P53 and VEGFA, ginsenoside Rb1 with CASP3, and formononetin with JUN. ADI can reduce the growth rate of tumor tissue and alleviate the structural abnormalities of tumor tissue. In ADI-mediated treatment of pancreatic cancer, ADI is expected to act on VEGFA, P53, CASP3, and JUN.

abstract: Multiple evidence ranging from molecular to cellular to epidemiological links nicotine transmission to the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease (AD). Here, we demonstrate the signaling mechanisms involved in nicotinic receptor-mediated protection against amyloid beta-enhanced glutamate neurotoxicity. Nicotine-induced protection can be enhanced by alpha-7 nicotinic receptor antagonists (alpha-bungarotoxin), phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) inhibitors (LY294002 wortmannin), and Src inhibitors (PP2) inhibition. Nicotine increases levels of phosphorylated Akt (a PI3K effector) and Bcl-2. The α7 nicotinic receptor is physically linked to the PI3K p85 subunit and Fyn. These results suggest that α7 nicotinic receptors transmit signals to PI3K in a cascade manner, ultimately exerting neuroprotective effects. This could form the basis for new treatments for Alzheimer's disease.

PP2’s action is explicitly linked to Alzheimer’s disease (AD) through its interaction with the nicotinic receptor signaling pathway, which is a key focus of the study.  2. **Mechanistic Insight Involving PP2**: The abstract details the mechanism by which the nicotinic receptor, particularly the alpha7 type, contributes to neuroprotection against beta-amyloid-enhanced neurotoxicity. It states that nicotine-induced protection is suppressed by PP2, implicating this drug in the modulation of neuroprotective signaling pathways relevant to AD pathology.  3. **Relevance to AD Pathogenesis and Treatment**: The integration of PP2 into the molecular study outlines its potential interference or modulation of a neuroprotective pathway in Alzheimer's disease. abstract: The development of single-molecule co-agonists of the glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP-1) receptor (GLP-1R) and glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP) receptors represents a breakthrough in obesity treatment. However, although the GIPR-GLP-1R agonist combination was more effective in reducing weight than the GLP-1R agonist alone in preclinical studies and clinical studies, 5 </sup>, the role of GIP in regulating energy metabolism remains unclear. Increasing evidence suggests that long-acting GIPR agonists act in the brain to reduce weight by inhibiting food intake<sup>3,6-8</sup>; however, the mechanisms by which GIP affects metabolism and neural populations Still to be determined. Here, we report that long-acting GIPR agonists and GIPR-GLP-1R agonists reduce body weight and food intake through inhibitory GABAergic neurons. We found that acyl-Gipr reduced body weight and food intake in diet-induced obese wild-type mice, but not in GABAergic neurons expressing Vgat (also known as Slc32a1) (Vgat-Gipr knockout). In mice, there was no effect. . However, in diet-induced obese wild-type male mice, the GIPR-GLP-1R co-agonist MAR709 resulted in greater weight loss and increased food intake inhibition compared with kinetically equivalent acyl-GLP-1 controls. , this superiority to GLP-1 disappeared in GFAT-GBR knockout mice. Our data indicate that long-acting GIPR agonists rely heavily on GABAergic inhibition of GIPR signaling in neurons to reduce body weight and food intake.

abstract: Glucose-dependent insulin polypeptide (GIP) plays a role in controlling postprandial metabolic tone. In humans, a GIP receptor (GIPR) variant (Q354, rs1800437) is associated with lower body mass index (BMI) and increased risk of type 2 diabetes. In order to better understand the effects of GIPR-Q354 on metabolism, it is necessary to understand. Study of the major GIPR isoform E354 in an isogenic background. To achieve this goal, we created GIPR-Q354 and GIPR-E354 mouse models using CRISPR-CAS9 editing. Here, we describe the metabolic effects of GIPR-Q354 variants in a mouse model (GIPR-Q350). We generated GIPR-Q350 mice to conduct in vivo studies of the metabolic effects of this variant. We isolated islets from GIPR-Q350 mice to study insulin secretion ex vivo. We used β-cell lines to understand the effects of GIPR-Q354 variants on receptor motility. We found that female GIPR-Q350 mice are smaller than littermates and that male GIPR-Q350 mice are resistant to diet-induced obesity, consistent with the association of this variant with lower BMI in humans. GIPR-Q350 mice of both sexes had greater glucose tolerance and were more sensitive to GIP. Postprandial GIP levels are reduced in GIPR-Q350 mice, revealing feedback regulation that balances the increased sensitivity of GIP target tissues to GIP secretion from enteroendocrine cells. The increase in ex vivo GIP sensitivity was reproducible when glucose-stimulated insulin secretion was measured in pancreatic islets. cAMP production in islets upon GIPR activation is not affected by Q354 substitution. However, upon activation the trafficking of GIPR-Q354 variants in β-cells is altered, characterized by prolonged intracellular residence time and increased localization to the trans-Golgi network (TGN). Our data link that controlled metabolism by GIP alters the intracellular flux of GIPR-Q354 variants. We propose that this change in spatiotemporal signaling underlies the physiological effects of GIPR-Q350/4 and GIPR-E350/4 in mice and humans. These findings contribute to a more comprehensive understanding of the effects of GIPR-Q354 variants on glucose homeostasis, which may be used to enhance pharmacological targeting of GIPR for the treatment of metabolic diseases.

abstract: Lipid signaling is dysregulated in many vascular diseases, including cancer, diabetic retinopathy, retinopathy of prematurity, and age-related macular degeneration. We have previously shown that a diet rich in omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) effectively reduces pathological retinal neovascularization in a mouse model of oxygen-induced retinopathy, in part through inhibition of cell-derived tumor necrosis factor metabolite. To better understand the protective effects of ω-3 PUFAs, we examined the relative importance of major lipid metabolism pathways and their products in contributing to this effect. When an omega-3 PUFA diet was fed to mice deficient in four major lipid-processing enzymes (cyclooxygenase 1 or 2, lipoxygenase 5 or 12/15), retinopathy was due to oxygen exposure; only 5 -Deletion of lipoxygenase (5-LOX) abolishes the protective effect of dietary PU-3 on retinopathy. This protective effect is due to the oxidation of the fatty acid docosahexaenoic acid ω-3 PUFA by 5-LOX to 4-hydroxy-docosahexaenoic acid (4-HDHA). 4-HDHA directly inhibits endothelial cell proliferation and angiogenesis via peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARγ), independent of the anti-inflammatory effects of 4-HDHA. Our study demonstrates that ω-3 PUFAs may serve as an alternative or complement to current vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) treatments for proliferative retinopathy and points to the use of ω-3 PUFAs and their metabolites in the treatment of diseases other than neovascularization. potential. It also states that cyclooxygenase inhibitors, such as aspirin and ibuprofen (but not lipoxygenase inhibitors, such as zileuton), can be used without losing the beneficial effects of an omega-3 PUFA diet.
